questions.text: Which of the following options is false in a patient with advanced liver disease?

options.label: D
options.text: Increased synthesis of glutamine and glutamine from alpha-ketoglutarate

questions.explanation:
Transamination Process
  • Transfer of an α-amino group from an amino acid to one keto acid, producing a new α-keto acid and a new amino acid.
  • The first step is the catabolism of most amino acids.
  • All amino acids, except Proline, hydroxyproline, threonine, and lysine, participate in transamination.

Biological Importance

Amino Acid Interconversion: Maintains balance of non-essential amino acids by transferring amino groups to synthesise needed amino acids.

Ammonia Disposal: Detoxifies ammonia by funnelling amino groups into glutamate, which is deaminated in the liver for excretion.
Glutamate's Role

α-Ketoglutarate: Acts as an acceptor of amino groups from most amino acids, converting to glutamate.
Transamination occurs in the cytoplasm; the amino group is transported to the liver as glutamate.

Oxidative Deamination: Glutamate undergoes rapid oxidative deamination in the mitochondria to form α-ketoglutarate, which can accept another amino group.
Enzymes

Aminotransferases (Transaminases): Catalyse the transfer of amino groups between carbon skeletons. They are not coenzymes.

Alanine Aminotransferase (ALT): Transfers amino group from alanine to α-ketoglutarate, forming pyruvate and glutamate.

Aspartate Aminotransferase (AST): Transfers amino groups from glutamate to oxaloacetate, forming aspartate used in the urea cycle.
Coenzyme Pyridoxal Phosphate (PLP): Required by all aminotransferases, derived from vitamin B6.
Reversibility Transamination reactions are reversible, with equilibrium constants near 1.

Activators of GDH

Inhibitors of GDH

NAD

ATP

ADP

GTP

GDP

NADH

A young girl presented to the OPD for an examination. She is tall and thin with slender fingers, and dislocated lenses. Workup revealed cystathione beta-synthase deficiency. Which amino acid supplement is required in this case?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Type - I Homocystinuria

Type - II Homocystinuria

Enzyme Deficiency

Cystathionine beta-synthase

Methionine synthase

Metabolic Pathway Affected

Homocysteine to cystathionine

Homocysteine to methionine

Elevated Metabolites

Homocysteine and methionine

Homocysteine and elevated levels of Cysteine

Biochemical Diagnosis
  • Low levels of cysteine.
  • High levels of methionine.
  • High levels of cysteine.
  • Low levels of methionine.

Treatment
  • Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) supplementation; low-methionine diet; cysteine supplementation

Vitamin B12 and folate supplementation; low-methionine diet

questions.text: A patient presented with joint pain and on evaluation, urine turns black on standing. What is the likely enzyme deficiency?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A: Homogentisic acid 1,2-dioxygenase

1. Homogentisic Aciduria

Presence of homogentisic acid in the urine, which turns dark upon standing or when exposed to air.

2. Ochronosis

Deposition of dark pigment in connective tissues, particularly noticeable in the ear cartilage, sclera, and other connective tissues, leading to a bluish-black discoloration.The image shows Osler’s sign.

3. Arthropathy

Degenerative joint disease, especially affecting the spine and large joints, leading to chronic pain and stiffness.

4. Cardiac Involvement

Includes heart valve calcification and atherosclerosis due to the deposition of pigment in cardiac tissues.

Reaction

Enzyme

Associated Disorder

Tyrosine → p-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate

Tyrosine transaminase

Tyrosinemia type II

p-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate → Homogentisate

p-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase

Tyrosinemia type III

Homogentisate → Maleylacetoacetate

Homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase

Alkaptonuria

Maleylacetoacetate → Fumarylacetoacetate

Maleylacetoacetate isomerase

-

Fumarylacetoacetate → Fumarate + Acetoacetate

Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase

Tyrosinemia type I

questions.text: An infant is brought by his parents with complaints that his urine turns black on standing. Which of the following metabolic disorders is most likely?
questions.explanation:
Alkaptonuria

Definition

Rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder caused by a deficiency of homogentisate 1,2 dioxygenase (HGD), an enzyme in the tyrosine metabolism pathway.

Mechanism and Pathophysiology

Defective tyrosine metabolism → homogentisic acid (HGA) accumulation → ochronotic pigment deposition → systemic disease (ochronosis).

 

  • Deficiency: HGD fails to convert HGA to maleylacetoacetate.
  • Consequences:
    • HGA oxidizes into melanin-like polymers → connective tissue deposition (ochronosis).
    • Affects joints, heart valves, kidneys, and vessels.

Clinical Features
  • Triad: Homogentisic aciduria, ochronosis, ochronotic osteoarthropathy.
  • Pediatric signs: Dark urine (oxidized HGA).
  • Musculoskeletal: Arthritis (spine, hips, knees), kyphoscoliosis, spinal stenosis.
  • Cardiac: Aortic stenosis, mitral valve disease, coronary artery disease.
  • Renal/Metabolic: Stones (renal, gallbladder, prostate).
  • Neurological: Peripheral neuropathy, stroke.

Evaluation
  • Clinical scoring: AKU Severity Score Index (AKUSSI).
  • Diagnostic tests:
    • Gold standard: Urinary HGA quantification via gas chromatography-mass spectrometry.
    • Genetic testing for HGD mutations.
    • Imaging (CT/MRI): Joint involvement, valvular calcification.
    • Echocardiography: Valvular abnormalities.

Management
  • Symptomatic: Pain control, physiotherapy, joint surgery.
  • Diet: Low-protein diet (limited efficacy).
  • Medications:
    • Vitamin C: Reduces HGA oxidation but not urinary excretion.
    • Nitisinone: Inhibits tyrosine metabolism, reduces HGA >95%. Side effects: tyrosinemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia.

Prognosis and Complications
  • Prognosis: Normal life expectancy; reduced quality of life (pain, sleep issues, disability).
  • Complications:
    • Stones (renal, gallbladder, salivary).
    • Tendon/ligament ruptures.
    • Osteopenia, fractures.
    • Aortic calcification/stenosis.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient is diagnosed with gouty arthritis. What biochemical changes will be seen in this patient?
questions.correct_answer: C. Increased urate and lactate levels
